temperature.title: Temperature
temperature.content:
Most relevant species of Campylobacter can grow at temperatures between 30°C and 42°C, although their optimal range is 37 to 42°C. Although they cannot grow below 30°C, they can nevertheless survive at lower temperatures and even during refrigeration at 4°C.
Campylobacter are highly sensitive to heat. For example, 90% of Campylobacter bacteria in minced meat will be inactivated in 9 minutes at 51°C, in 4.85 min at 53°C and in 0.79 min at 57°C.

oxygen.title: Oxygen
oxygen.content: Campylobacter are “microaerophilic” organisms, meaning that they require oxygen, but at a lower concentration (3-15%) than in the atmosphere (21%), and with a high concentration of carbon dioxide (10% CO2).

ph.title: pH
ph.content: Campylobacter cannot survive below a pH of 4.9 or above pH 9.0. They grow optimally at a pH of 6.5 to 7.5.

humidity.title: Water
humidity.content: Campylobacter can grow with a water activity (aw) > 0.987. They are therefore highly sensitive to dry environments.

salinity.title: Salinity
salinity.content: Campylobacter have a low tolerance to salt, and cannot grow at sodium chloride concentrations above 2.0%, with optimal growth at 0.5%. These concentrations are far lower than in foods where salt is used as preservative.
